awd_titl_txt: CRII: SCH: Analysis of Population-Based Image Metamorphosis
awd_abstract_narration:
Uncovering brain development and disease progression can ultimately advance our understanding of brain disorders, such as mental illnesses and brain cancer. However, the analysis of early brain growth and pathological anatomy changes in brain scans needs image metamorphosis that can jointly capture structural changes occurring in a developing brain and appearance changes introduced by brain myelination and tumor growth. This project aims to develop statistical and computational models to summarize these metamorphic changes from image pairs, to sequences, and to populations. By enriching our knowledge of the healthy brain, psychopathologies, and brain pathologies, this research has the potential to provide clues in devising treatment strategies for brain disorders.

The focus of this project is the development of population-based image metamorphosis that accounts for brain structure and image appearance changes simultaneously. The essential component of the developed model is an advanced image-to-image metamorphosis that allows establishing brain mappings between image pairs. This project develops a novel metamorphic regression model to handle image sequences and estimate age-related brain changes in image time-series. The population analysis component leverages the regression model and statistical tools for classification and assessment of typical and atypical brain changes. The primary applications of the developed image metamorphosis models are studies of early brain development and brain tumor growth. The resulting models could be applied to understand the etiology of developmental disorders and psychiatric conditions, such as autism, schizophrenia, and bipolar disease. They could also monitor brain tumor growth through predicting tumor evolution and classifying tumor type and grade.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we have developed a set of novel and fast metamorphosis models for deformable image registration, segmentation, and regression at three different levels, i.e., image pairs, image time series, and image populations. First, we proposed an atlas-based deep metamorphosis model, which can jointly estimate the spatial deformation and intensity changes between images using deep neural networks. This model does not require the prior knowledge of the intensity changes or their segmentation as input. We tested the proposed model on synthetic data in four different scenarios: (1) both source and target images have no intensity changes; (2) only source image has intensity changes; (3) only target image has intensity changes; (4) both source and target images have intensity changes. The model can correctly handle all four scenarios without needing any special care.

Second, we proposed an adversarial based selective cutting network (ASC-Net), which bridges the two domains of cluster based deep learning methods and adversarial-based anomaly/novelty detection algorithms. Compared to previous methods like the AnoGAN family, our model obtains performance gains in unsupervised anomaly segmentation tasks, such as BraTS brain tumor segmentation, LiTS liver lesion segmentation, and MS-SEG2015 segmentation.

Third, we proposed a multi-scale diffeomorphic registration model that tackles the problem of registration and outperforms the state-of-the-art methods on the OASIS and BRATs datasets. We have also proposed a technique that handles pathological image registration, by introducing the masks of the pathological regions. Since masks are only needed in loss calculation, we only need them during training, and the trained network can be directly used to warp a new pair of normal or pathological regions.

Fourth, we proposed new diffeomorphic image registration models by using Residual Networks as numerical approximations of the underlying diffeomorphic setting, governed by ordinary differential equations (ODEs). This method uses both stationary velocity fields and time varying velocity fields, as the driving velocities to solve the ODEs, which gives rise to the two proposed architectures. Experimental results demonstrate that our models are computation efficient and achieve comparable registration results with a smoother deformation field.

The major results of this project have led to multiple papers published on renowned conferences in medical image analysis, such as MICCAI and ISBI. Moreover, some outcomes of this project have been incorporated into several undergraduate and graduate courses at the University of Georgia (UGA), such as Data Science I and Advanced Representation Learning. Some students have chosen relevant topics on medical image analysis as their course projects. In addition, high school students participated into this project through the UGA Young Dawgs Program, working on the brain tumor segmentation. Through this experience, students have developed interests in applying artificial intelligence techniques to medical problems.
